text: in West Africa health experts believe
that Ebola could infect hundreds of
thousands more before it may be brought
under control the number of new cases is
moving faster than the capacity to
manage them with 3,000 US military
personnel headed to the region the
challenges ahead for the US and some
differences between this effort and the
mission following Haiti's 2010
earthquake now on the new york times
minute after the earthquake in haiti the
u.s. mobilized navy equipment doctors
and thousands of marines officials
distributed relief supplies and treated
injured and diseased patients the
response was seen as effective even
though many aid workers acted from a
distance on navy ship named the comfort
treated haitians offshore Ebola will be
much more complex because of the
contagious nature of the disease any
large-scale evacuations will likely be
too risky so US personnel will need to
operate on the ground an urgent task
along with community intervention will
be setting up facilities to assist the
region's overloaded medical system and
our forces are going to bring their
expertise in command and control in
logistics in engineering and our
Department of Defense is better at that
our armed services veteran than at that
than any organization on earth in the
months ahead experts expect that the
main problem will be recruiting highly
trained health care workers not just
military personnel to risk their lives
in the infected zones the World Health
Organization estimates that at least 500
doctors and over 1,000 healthcare
workers will be needed to turn the tide
and the disease the US military will
provide some of that expertise but the
question is whether will be enough I
don't see if that is the lack of money
there's a lot of countries donors that
are throwing money at us we don't have
the resources in terms of human
resources a capacity to run more Ebola
